name: methyl_ethyl_sulfide
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: 1,3-propanedithiol has a melting point of -106.0 degrees Celsius. The basic unit for this compound can be considered ethanethiol (with a melting point of -106.0 degrees Celsius) because the methyl and ethyl groups will significantly alter the physical properties compared to a straight-chain butene isomer. For the methyl-ethyl-sulfide specifically, the introduction of the four-membered ring introduces ring strain and a more rigid structure, but also reduces the symmetry. This reduction in symmetry and presence of strain usually leads to a higher melting point. However, the exact impact of ring formation is difficult to quantify without experimental data or detailed computational studies. Ring formation: +35°C (This is a rough estimate and may not reflect the exact value for such structural modifications).
